sen.j: 司箭院 興仙（しせんいん こうせん、生没年不詳）は、戦国時代 (日本)の武将、山伏、僧侶。
sen.e: Shisen'in Kosen (the date of birth and death unknown) was busho (Japanese military commander), yamabushi (a mountain priest) and Buddhist monk in the Sengoku period (the period of warring states.)
Shisen'in Kosen (the date of birth and death unknown) was busho (Japanese military commander), yamabushi (a mountain priest) and Buddhist monk in the Sengoku period (the period of warring states.)
Shisenin Kosen (year of birth and death unknown) was busho (Japanese military commander), yamabushi (a mountain priest) and Buddhist monk in the Sengoku period (the period of warring states.)

sen.j: 本名は宍戸家俊といい安芸宍戸氏の一族である。
sen.e: His real name was Ietoshi SHISHIDO and he was from a family of the Aki-Shishido clan.
sen.cmt: 安芸宍戸氏→the Aki-Shishido Family（データベース）、Familyは誤りでclanと判断しました。
sen.e: His real name was Ietoshi SHISHIDO and he was from a family of the Aki-Shishido clan.
His real name was Ietoshi SHISHIDO and he was from a family of the Aki-Shishido clan.

sen.j: 父は後期宍戸氏の初代宍戸元家、息子に宍戸源次郎。
sen.e: His father was the first Motoie SHISHIDO in the later years of the Shishido clan and his son was Genjiro SHISHIDO.
His father was the first Motoie SHISHIDO in the later years of the Shishido clan and his son was Genjiro SHISHIDO.
His father was the first Motoie SHISHIDO in the later years of the Shishido clan and his son was Genjiro SHISHIDO.

sen.j: 毛利氏の一門として活躍した宍戸隆家の大叔父にあたる。
sen.e: He was a grand-uncle of Takaie SHISHIDO who played an active role as a family of the Mori clan.
He was a grand-uncle of Takaie SHISHIDO who played an active role as a family of the Mori clan.
He was a grand-uncle of Takaie SHISHIDO who played an active role as a family of the Mori clan.

sen.j: その生涯は不明な点が多いが、安芸宍戸氏の一族として生まれた。
sen.e: Much of his history was unclear, but he was born in a family of the Aki-Shishido clan.
Much of his history was unclear, but he was born in a family of the Aki-Shishido clan.
Much of his history was unclear, but he was born in a family of the Aki-Shishido clan.

sen.j: 兄の深瀬隆兼の養子となり、祝屋城と深瀬城を預かったが、家俊は山伏に身をやつして修行に明け暮れ、一時期備中国にも居住している。
sen.e: After he was adopted by his older brother Takakane FUKASE (深瀬隆兼,) he was asked to take care of Iwaya castle and Fukase castle, but Ietoshi devoted himself in being the yamabushi and spent a whole day to practice, and used to live in Bicchu Province for a period of time.

After he was adopted by his older brother Takakane FUKASE (深瀬隆兼,) he was asked to take care of Iwaya and Fukase castles, but Ietoshi devoted himself to being yamabushi and spent a whole day practicing, and used to live in Bicchu Province for a period of time.

After he was adopted by his older brother Takakane FUKASE, he was asked to take care of Iwaya-jo and Fukase-jo castles, but Ietoshi devoted himself to being yamabushi and spent a whole day practicing, and used to live in Bicchu Province for a period of time.
sen.cmt: (深瀬隆兼,)削除→読み方不明用語統一

sen.j: 修行の末に由利正俊より源義経以来の家伝の法を伝えられ、愛宕信仰を信仰して飛行自由を得、その技は神業とされるほどであった。
sen.e: At the end of his practice, Masatoshi YURI (由利正俊) disclosed him a certain method of his family tradition, which had been last handed down to MINAMOTO no Yoshitsune, and Ietoshi acquired the skill to fly freely through believing the Atago-shinko faith and was thought to have even a superhuman feat because of that skill.

At the end of his practice, Masatoshi YURI (由利正俊) disclosed to him, a certain method from his family tradition, which had been handed down to MINAMOTO no Yoshitsune, and Ietoshi acquired the skill to fly freely through believing the Atago-shinko faith and was thought to have skills causing superhuman feat.

At the end of his practice, Masatoshi YURI disclosed to him, a certain method from his family tradition, which had been handed down to MINAMOTO no Yoshitsune, and Ietoshi acquired the skill to fly freely through believing the Atago-shinko faith and was thought to have skills causing superhuman feat.

sen.j: 明応3年（1494年）、京都に上った後に鞍馬寺で「天狗の法」を行う興仙の噂を聞きつけた唐橋という人物が、その正体を確かめようと東福寺の僧侶を引きつれ鞍馬寺へ参ると、先に細川政元が興仙の宿所に来ていた。
sen.e: After a man called KURAHASHI heard about Kosen who went to Kyoto and was performing 'Tengu Method' at Kurama-dera Temple in 1494, he visited Kurama-dera Temple together with Buddhist monks of Tofuku-ji Temple to confirm what Kosen was like and found that Masamoto HOSOKAWA had got in the accommodations of Kosen.

After a man called KURAHASHI heard about Kosen who went to Kyoto and was performing the 'Tengu Method' at Kurama-dera Temple in 1494, he visited Kurama-dera Temple together with Buddhist monks of Tofuku-ji Temple to confirm what Kosen was like and found that Masamoto HOSOKAWA had gotten accommodations at Kosen.

After a man called Kurahashi heard about Kosen who went to Kyoto and was performing the 'Tengu Method' at Kurama-dera Temple in 1494, he visited Kurama-dera Temple together with Buddhist monks of Tofuku-ji Temple to confirm what Kosen was like and found that Masamoto HOSOKAWA had gotten accommodations at Kosen.

sen.j: 夜も更けた頃、興仙・政元・唐橋らが酒を飲んで語るうち、興仙は「法の奥義は、言葉では表せない」と短冊に「張良化現大天魔源義経神」と書いて見せたので、僧侶たちは怖がって逃げた、という話が、公家の日記に残っている。
sen.e: There is a story in the diary of a certain court noble that when drinking with Masamoto and Karahashi around the time the evening went on, Kosen told them that 'I can't talk about the secrets of the method by words' and wrote '張良化現大天魔源義経神' on tanzaku (a long, narrow card on which Japanese poems are usually written vertically), so the monks fled out of fear.

There is a story in the diary of a certain court noble that while drinking with Masamoto and Karahashi in the evening, Kosen told them that 'I can't talk about the secrets of the method with words' and wrote '張良化現大天魔源義経神' on tanzaku (a long, narrow card on which Japanese poems are usually written vertically), and the monks fled out of fear.

There is a story in the diary of a certain court noble that while drinking with Masamoto and Karahashi in the evening, Kosen told them that 'I can't talk about the secrets of the method with words' and wrote '張良化現大天魔源義経神' on tanzaku (a long, narrow card on which Japanese poems are usually written vertically), and the monks fled out of fear.

sen.j: そして細川京兆家の細川政元に仕えたとされる。
sen.e: He is thought to have served for Masamoto HOSOKAWA of the Hosokawa-keicho family.
He is thought to have served for Masamoto HOSOKAWA of the Hosokawa-keicho family.
He is thought to have served for Masamoto HOSOKAWA of the Hosokawa-keicho family.

sen.j: 細川政元が修験道に凝っていたことは有名で、司箭院興仙もその才をもって迎えられた。
sen.e: It is well known that Masamoto HOSOKAWA was really into Shugendo (Japanese mountain asceticism-shamanism incorporating Shinto and Buddhist concepts,) and that's why Shinsen'in Kosen was invited because of his talent.

It is well known that Masamoto HOSOKAWA was really into Shugendo (Japanese mountain asceticism-shamanism incorporating Shinto and Buddhist concepts,) and that's why Shinsen'in Kosen was invited because of his talent.

It is well known that Masamoto HOSOKAWA was really into Shugendo (Japanese mountain asceticism-shamanism incorporating Shinto and Buddhist concepts,) and that's why Shisenin Kosen was invited because of his talent.

sen.j: 「後慈眼院殿御記」には上洛した興仙が政元に兵法を指導した件が記述されている。
sen.e: It is described in '後慈眼院殿御記' that Kosen went to Kyoto and taught Masamoto the art of warfare.
It is described in '後慈眼院殿御記' that Kosen went to Kyoto and taught Masamoto the art of warfare.
It is described in '後慈眼院殿御記' that Kosen went to Kyoto and taught Masamoto the art of warfare.

sen.j: 「和長卿記」の明応9年（1500年）に京都で大火が起き、細川政元の第一の家臣の家も焼けたという記載があり、その中に興仙の名前が挙がっている。
sen.e: There is a description in '和長卿記 ' that when a big fire broke out in Kyoto in 1500, the house of the most important vassal of Masamoto HOSOKAWA was burnt down, too and the name of Kosen was seen in it.
There is a description in '和長卿記 ' that when a big fire broke out in Kyoto in 1500, the house of the most important vassal of Masamoto HOSOKAWA was burnt down too and the name of Kosen was seen in it.

There is a description in 'Kazunaga Kyo Ki' (the Diary of Kazunaga Higashibojo) that when a big fire broke out in Kyoto in 1500, the house of the most important vassal of Masamoto HOSOKAWA was burnt down too and the name of Kosen was seen in it.
sen.cmt: '和長卿記 '→'Kazunaga Kyo Ki' (the Diary of Kazunaga Higashibojo

sen.j: 1507年にも三条西実隆が「実隆公記」において、山城国内の三条西家の所領について、興仙を通じて細川政元に訴訟の円滑化を働きかけている。
sen.e: According to 'Sanetaka koki (Sanetaka's diary)' written by Sanetaka SANJONISHI, Sanetaka asked Masamoto HOSOKAWA for speedy lawsuit on Sanjonishi family's territories in Yamashiro Province through Kosen in 1507.

According to 'Sanetaka koki (Sanetaka's diary)' written by Sanetaka SANJONISHI, Sanetaka asked Masamoto HOSOKAWA for a speedy lawsuit concerning Sanjonishi family's territories in Yamashiro Province through Kosen in 1507.

According to 'Sanetaka koki' (Sanetaka's diary) written by Sanetaka SANJONISHI, Sanetaka asked Masamoto HOSOKAWA for a speedy lawsuit concerning Sanjonishi family's territories in Yamashiro Province through Kosen in 1507.

sen.j: この件からも興仙は政元の側近として大きな権力を持っていたことがうかがえる。
sen.e: This incident tells us that Kosen seemed to have a significant power as Masamoto's close adviser.
This incident tells us that Kosen seemed to have a significant power as Masamoto's close adviser.
This incident tells us that Kosen seemed to have a significant power as Masamoto's close adviser.

sen.j: 権力の座にあった細川政元が、細川澄之派に籠絡された側近の竹田孫七・香西元長・薬師寺長忠によって、湯殿で行水をしていたところを襲われて殺された（永正の錯乱）。
sen.e: When Masamoto HOSOKAWA in power was bathing in a bathroom, he was attacked and killed by Magoshichi TAKEDA, Motonaga KOUZAI and Nagatada Yakushiji (薬師寺長忠) as close advisers who were deceived by Sumimoto HOSOKAWA group (Eisho no Sakuran (assassination of Masamoto HOSOKAWA.)

When Masamoto HOSOKAWA was in power and was bathing, he was attacked and killed by Magoshichi TAKEDA, Motonaga KOUZAI and Nagatada Yakushiji (薬師寺長忠) as close advisers who were deceived by the Sumimoto HOSOKAWA group (Eisho no Sakuran (assassination of Masamoto HOSOKAWA.)

When Masamoto HOSOKAWA was in power and was bathing, he was attacked and killed by Magoshichi TAKEDA, Motonaga KOZAI and Nagatada YAKUSHIJI as close advisers who were deceived by the Sumimoto HOSOKAWA group (Eisho no Sakuran (assassination of Masamoto HOSOKAWA).
sen.cmt: (薬師寺長忠)削除人名修正ピリオド位置移動

sen.j: その後、興仙は出家した模様で、1509年の実隆日記で興仙は僧正になっていることも記載されている。
sen.e: Meanwhile, Kosen seemed to enter into priesthood, and Sanataka's diary of the year 1509 states Kosen became a priest.
Meanwhile, Kosen seemed to enter into priesthood, and Sanataka's diary of the year 1509 states Kosen became a priest.
Meanwhile, Kosen seemed to enter into priesthood, and Sanetaka's diary of the year 1509 states Kosen became a priest.

sen.j: 元亀元年（1570年）4月4日、興仙は安芸国祝屋から空中に飛行し、京都愛宕山を住処としたという。
sen.e: Kosen is thought to have flown in the air from Iwaya, Aki Province on May 18, 1570, and decided to live in Mt. Atago in Kyoto.
Kosen is thought to have flown in the air from Iwaya, Aki Province on May 18, 1570, and decided to live on Mt. Atago in Kyoto.
Kosen is thought to have flown in the air from Iwaya, Aki Province on May 18, 1570, and decided to live on Mt. Atago in Kyoto.

sen.j: 後に興仙はその秘術を河野通昭に伝えたとされる。
sen.e: Afterward, Kosen is believed to have handed down the secret art to Michiaki Kawano (河野通昭.)
Afterward, Kosen is believed to have handed down the secret art to Michiaki Kawano (河野通昭.)
Afterward, Kosen is believed to have handed down the secret art to Michiaki KAWANO.

sen.j: 兵法・妖術にその才を発揮しただけでなく、剣術や槍術、薙刀にも秀で、剣術は貫心流、薙刀は司箭流と呼ばれ、
sen.e: He showed the ability not only in the art of warfare and magic art but also swordplay, the art of the spearman ship and naginata (Japanese halberd), and his swordplay and naginata were called 貫心流 and 司箭流, respectively.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: He showed the ability not only in the art of warfare and magic art, but also swordplay, the art of the spearman ship and naginata (Japanese halberd), and his swordplay and naginata were called 貫心流 and 司箭流, respectively.

He showed the ability not only in the art of warfare and magic art, but also swordplay, the art of the spearman ship and naginata (Japanese halberd), and his swordplay and naginata were called Kanshin school and Shisen School, respectively.
sen.cmt: 貫心流削除→kanshin schoolとしました。司箭流削除→Shisen schoolとしました。

sen.j: その武術は河野大蔵通昭に伝えられ、後に広島藩に仕えた築山通護（河野から改姓）がその剣術を伝え、広島藩の剣術の主流となった。
sen.e: His martial art was handed down to 河野大蔵通昭, and afterward, 築山通護 (former family name was 河野) who worked for Hiroshima Domain taught the martial art and it was a main martial art in Hiroshima Domain.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: His martial art was handed down to 河野大蔵通昭, and afterward, 築山通護 (former family name was 河野) who worked for Hiroshima Domain, taught the martial art and it was a main martial art in Hiroshima Domain.

His martial art was handed down to Okura Michiaki KAWANO, and afterward, 築山通護 (former family name was Kawano) who worked for Hiroshima Domain, taught the martial art and it was a main martial art in Hiroshima Domain.
sen.cmt: 河野大蔵通昭削除→読み方不明ですが、Okura Michiaki KAWANOとしました。河野削除→Kawano

sen.j: 安芸宍戸氏の拠点であった五龍城には現在も司箭院興仙を祀る司箭神社が残っている。
sen.e: There is still Shisen Shrine which worships Shisen'in Kosen in Goryo-jo Castle as the base of the Aki-Shishido clan.
The Shisen Shrine still exists that worships Shisen'in Kosen in Goryo-jo Castle, as the base of the Aki-Shishido clan.
The Shisen Shrine still exists that worships Shisenin Kosen in Goryo-jo Castle, as the base of the Aki-Shishido clan.

sen.j: その没年は不詳だが、父の元家（1432～1509年）の生年と、兄の深瀬隆兼の養子となった件から、兄と興仙は年齢が15歳程度は違った兄弟で、細川政元と同年代かやや年下だと推測される。
sen.e: Although the date of death is unknown, he seems to have been younger by around fifteen years than his older brother and be as old as or slightly younger than Masamoto HOSOKAWA, judging from the date of birth of his father Motoie (1432-1509) and the incident that he was adopted by his older brother Takakane FUKASE.

Although the date of death is unknown, he seems to have been younger by around fifteen years than his older brother and as old as or slightly younger than Masamoto HOSOKAWA, judging from the date of birth of his father Motoie (1432-1509) and the incident about him being adopted by his older brother Takakane FUKASE.

Although the year of death is unknown, he seems to have been younger by around fifteen years than his older brother and as old as or slightly younger than Masamoto HOSOKAWA, judging from the year of birth of his father Motoie (1432-1509) and the incident about him being adopted by his older brother Takakane FUKASE.

sen.j: そのため1570年に愛宕山に入った頃は100歳を超えていたと思われる。
sen.e: Therefore, when he entered Mr. Atago in 1570, he is thought to have been over the age of a hundred years.
Therefore, when he entered Mr. Atago in 1570, he was thought to have been over the age of a hundred years.
Therefore, when he entered Mt. Atago in 1570, he was thought to have been over the age of a hundred years.

sen.j: 一説には文明 (日本)18年（1486年）生まれとされるが、父の年齢と、細川政元に仕えた年齢がわずか9歳ということから否定されている。
sen.e: According to a certain tradition, he was born in 1486, but it has been denied because of his father's age and a background that he was only nine years old when he was serving for Masamoto HOSOKAWA.

According to a certain tradition, he was born in 1486, but this has been denied because of his father's age and a background that actually he was only nine years old when he was serving Masamoto HOSOKAWA.

According to a certain tradition, he was born in 1486, but this has been denied because of his father's age and a background that actually he was only nine years old when he was serving Masamoto HOSOKAWA.
